questions.question: What is write endurance?
questions.explanation: Write endurance: total data writes possible. Measured: TBW (terabytes written). Typical: 150-600 TBW for consumer SSDs. Importance: consumer SSDs rarely hit limit. Longevity: typically lasts years.

questions.question: What is wear leveling?
questions.explanation: Wear leveling: distributes writes across cells. Purpose: extends SSD lifespan. Techniques: dynamic, static. Automatic: firmware handles. Benefit: prevents premature failure.

questions.question: What is TRIM?
questions.explanation: TRIM: OS tells SSD about deletions. Purpose: improve SSD performance. Automatic: modern OSes support. Benefit: maintains speed over time. Required: must be enabled.

questions.question: What is overprovisioning?
questions.explanation: Overprovisioning: extra space reserved. Purpose: wear leveling, performance. Typical: 7-28% reserved. Invisible: users don't see. Benefit: extends lifespan.

questions.question: What is a memory page?
questions.explanation: Memory page: standard size block. Size: typically 4KB. Purpose: virtual memory, paging. Management: OS handles. Translation: page table used. Concept: basis of VM.

questions.question: What is virtual memory?
questions.explanation: Virtual memory: extends RAM with storage. Speed: much slower than RAM. Purpose: run large programs. Management: OS automatic. Swapping: data moves to disk. Overhead: reduces performance.

questions.question: What is memory bandwidth?
questions.explanation: Memory bandwidth: speed of data movement. Measured: GB/s typically. Importance: performance impact. Factors: bus width, speed. Saturation: can become bottleneck.

questions.question: What is IOPS?
questions.explanation: IOPS: random access speed measure. Used: storage performance metric. Typical: SSDs 50,000-100,000 IOPS. Typical: HDDs 100-200 IOPS. Database: workload depends on.

questions.question: What is latency?
questions.explanation: Latency: delay to retrieve data. Measured: milliseconds (HDD), microseconds (SSD). Importance: affects responsiveness. Factors: seek time, rotation. SSD: much lower than HDD.

questions.question: What is a hybrid drive?
questions.explanation: Hybrid drive: combines both technologies. Speed: faster than pure HDD. Capacity: large like HDD. Cost: moderate between both. Performance: depends on usage patterns. Decline: becoming obsolete.
